title: As a beginner, will a short scale bass be better for me? - Quora

response.answer_text: I played long scale bass all my life, and I tried a short scale one not long ago. It was fun to play. Different, but fun! I still prefer the long scale, but I see nothing wrong with the short scale one. To answer your question, “better” is what suits you and your style. It’s not a matter of long or short scale. It’s a matter of what feels right for YOU. My advise: Go to a music shop and try both. See which one feels better. THe instrument will talk to you. And then, you can make a choice. But there’s one thing to remember: It’s also not a matter of being abeginner or a pro. It’s about the instrument you choose. If you pick the short scale bass, be ready to master the short scale bass. Same with the long scale bass. Don’t think for a minute: “I’ll start with the short scale and when I become a pro, I’ll switch to the long scale”. Music doesn’t work like that. The difference between a beginner and a pro is not the instrument, but the “mileage”. You don’t pick an instrument to discard it after a while. You pick an instrument to master it, and get it to the limit. I continue playing the first bass I bought. I modified it a lot, but it’s still my good old first bass.

I wouldn’t have said so, per se. I started on a short scale bass (a Fender Mustang) way back in nineteen hundred and tiddlybonk, but sold it to buy a two pickup Ibanez bass. It was nice to play. I often wish I still had it. The only reasons I can think of for a short scale being better for a beginner are size/weight, but weight can depend on the kind of wood used in a bass, whatever scale. Neck width on a long scale bass might make a difference if you had small hands. I immediately thought of the amazing Tal Wilkenfeld , who looks quite small and dainty, but plays full size, long scale basses and does a pretty damn good job of it. Short scale basses can sound different, but aren’t necessarily any easier to use. EDIT: Tal Wilkenfeld live (with full size bass) Jeff Beck & Tal Wilkenfeld. @ Crossroads Festival 2007

Short answer: Maybe. Longer answer: Short-scale (30″) basses were developed so that guitarists who wanted to play bass could adapt more easily. For example, Gibson's EB series (EB-1, EB-0, EB-2, EB-3, etc.) all started out as short-scale, with full-scale (34″) versions of some models available later. Fender's Precision and Jazz Bass were both full-scale, with the short-scale Mustang and Musicmaster basses coming later. If you want to learn proper bass technique, a full-scale bass is almost a necessity; the strings on short-scale models don't have as much string tension, which affects playing style. If you have REALLY small hands, a short-scale bass will work, but a full-scale is preferable.

It depends on what your playing goal is, both technically and tonally. Shorter scale basses have a weaker sound and shorter sustain than longer scale basses, which is fine if you like the tone of the short scale. But learning on a short scale bass will put you at a disadvantage whenever you decided to make the switch to a longer scale bass. I have witnessed this personally with someone I am teaching. She made the switch to a longer scale bass after practicing mainly with a short scale and she's still having trouble adjusting to the new scale length. I reccomend learning on a long scale and later if you prefer the tone of a short scale, then switch to that. Learning on a long scale will give you more technical flexibility.

The Hofner bass is short scale (30.5”) and McCartney used it forever. Jack Bruce played a short scale. Nothing wrong with it. Is a short bass easier to learn on? If you already play guitar, then probably. Otherwise, there is no reason to switch scale lengths once you get better. (You can also get “in between” scales like 32” from some manufacturers.)

No. Choosing short scale on a bass is purely a tonal and physical choice. You choose a short scale bass because you like the tone, or because it is literally impossible for you to perform on a full-sized bass because you are a small person. Skill level does not determine which scale length should be used.

Yes! Contrary to what others have said there is nothing wrong with using a short scale bass as your main bass. They are great for beginners and experts alike. They sound a little different than long scale basses but every bass sounds a little different from each other so that’s not a big deal. An excellent beginner bass would be the Ibanez Mikro 24” bass. It’s cheap, small and has a killer tone!
nope, get the normal scale bass. so someday u will not confuse if u play or buy expensive normal scale bass. So many great basses with normal scale bass size, the sound also killer

Short scale basses are (slightly) easier to play, but I would go with a long scale if you can manage it - if you can comfortably place your fingers on the first four frets . I started on a short scale and moved up to a long scale later
You might find it’s better all around….short scale basses are perfect for players with smaller hands, just be sure you find one that’s balanced well so it’s easy to stand and play…..
If you're taller than 5'2" I'd go for a full scale bass, you'd miss out quite a bit in terms of sound on a short scale. And you'd want a full scale pretty soon anyway. Cheers.
